description: Enterprise techniques used by APT33, ATT&CK group G0064 v1.3
name: APT33 (G0064)

techniques.comment: APT33 has used HTTP for command and control.[3]
APT33 has used WinRAR to compress data prior to exfil.[3]
APT33 has deployed a tool known as DarkComet to the Startup folder of a victim, and used Registry run keys to gain persistence.[3][5]
APT33 has used password spraying to gain access to target systems.[4][5]
APT33 has utilized PowerShell to download files from the C2 server and run various scripts. [3][5]
APT33 has used VBScript to initiate the delivery of payloads.[5]
APT33 has used a variety of publicly available tools like LaZagne to gather credentials.[3][4]
APT33 has used a variety of publicly available tools like LaZagne to gather credentials.[3][4]
APT33 has used base64 to encode command and control traffic.[4]
APT33 has used AES for encryption of command and control traffic.[4]
APT33 has attempted to use WMI event subscriptions to establish persistence on compromised hosts.[5]
APT33 has used FTP to exfiltrate files (separately from the C2 channel).[3]
APT33 has attempted to exploit a known vulnerability in WinRAR (CVE-2018-20250), and attempted to gain remote code execution via a security bypass vulnerability (CVE-2017-11774).[3][5]
APT33 has used a publicly available exploit for CVE-2017-0213 to escalate privileges on a local system.[4]
APT33 has downloaded additional files and programs from its C2 server.[3][5]
APT33 has used SniffPass to collect credentials by sniffing network traffic.[3]
APT33 has used HTTP over TCP ports 808 and 880 for command and control.[3]
APT33 has used base64 to encode payloads.[4]
APT33 has used a variety of publicly available tools like LaZagne, Mimikatz, and ProcDump to dump credentials.[3][4]
APT33 has used a variety of publicly available tools like LaZagne to gather credentials.[3][4]
APT33 has used a variety of publicly available tools like LaZagne to gather credentials.[3][4]
APT33 has sent spearphishing emails containing links to .hta files.[1][3]
APT33 has sent spearphishing e-mails with archive attachments.[5]
APT33 has created a scheduled task to execute a .vbe file multiple times a day.[3]
APT33 has used a variety of publicly available tools like LaZagne to gather credentials.[3][4]
APT33 has used a variety of publicly available tools like Gpppassword to gather credentials.[3][4]
APT33 has lured users to click links to malicious HTML applications delivered via spearphishing emails.[1][3]
APT33 has used malicious e-mail attachments to lure victims into executing malware.[5]
APT33 has used valid accounts for initial access and privilege escalation.[2][4]
APT33 has used compromised Office 365 accounts in tandem with Ruler in an attempt to gain control of endpoints.[5]
